tiaraki wrote on 11.10.2010 4:10:
> Although junit is designed to run the test methods in arbitrary order,

A related issue is that Java's reflection libraries do not return the 
methods in the same order as they are declared in the source code. It's 
compiler-dependant that in which order the methods are written to the 
.class file - sometimes they are in order, sometimes in reverse order, 
sometimes in random order.

Some time ago I wrote a tool for sorting methods (and inner classes) 
according to their line numbers and it's being used in the JDave testing 
framework. It sorts them by reading the line numbers from the bytecode. 
The source code is at http://github.com/orfjackal/classmembersorter

-- 
Esko Luontola
